community.message: You fixed a bug of your garbage collector.
Your git pull is bigger than you thought.
You have programmed something good and received a donation that allows you to host your program externally.
Finally, your data-intensive program is finished with the calculation.
You make some optimizations to your program.
You create a comprehensive syntax highlighting package for your programming language.
You need more memory for your data.
You delete plugins that you never use.
You remove whitespace characters from your JSON files.
You delete one of the many IDEs/editors that you hardly ever open.

chance.message: Your educational institution wants you to use this programming language.
HTTP/307 Temporary Redirect. The ancient project that is assigned to you uses this programming language.
You receive many upvotes for your question. Your friends think you're so cool that they offer to let you use their storage.

You get hundreds of downvotes for your question. Your self-confidence drops so low that you go into isolation on your own to avoid committing any more code crimes. (You'll get better soon, believe me.)
It's time to move on to more advanced programming languages.
You help someone with a lot of downvotes with a nice comment. The karma pays off, as you realize through your research how you can fix self-pointing pointers not being garbage collected.
